segment.source: Learn how to add application ID and ad unit ID values from the Windows Dev Center dashboard to your app before you submit your app to the Store.
segment.target: Learn how to add application ID and ad unit ID values from the Windows Dev Center dashboard to your app before you submit your app to the Store.

segment.source: Set up ad units in your app
segment.target: Set up ad units in your app

segment.source: Set up ad units in your app
segment.target: Set up ad units in your app

segment.source: Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive

segment.source: When you use an AdControl or InterstitialAd to display ads in your app, you must specify an application ID and ad unit ID.
segment.target: When you use an AdControl or InterstitialAd to display ads in your app, you must specify an application ID and ad unit ID.

segment.source: While you are developing your app, use the appropriate test application ID and ad unit ID values to see how your app renders ads during testing.
segment.target: While you are developing your app, use the appropriate test application ID and ad unit ID values to see how your app renders ads during testing.

segment.source: After you finish testing your app and you are ready to submit it to Windows Dev Center, you must update your app code to use application ID and ad unit ID values from the Windows Dev Center dashboard.
segment.target: After you finish testing your app and you are ready to submit it to Windows Dev Center, you must update your app code to use application ID and ad unit ID values from the Windows Dev Center dashboard.

segment.source: If you try to use test values in your live app, your app will not receive live ads.
segment.target: If you try to use test values in your live app, your app will not receive live ads.

segment.source: To set up the application ID and ad units for your live app:
segment.target: To set up the application ID and ad units for your live app:

segment.source: On the Windows Dev Center dashboard, select your app and then click Monetization > Monetize with ads.
segment.target: On the Windows Dev Center dashboard, select your app and then click Monetization > Monetize with ads.

segment.source: In the Microsoft Advertising ad units section on this page, create an ad unit.
segment.target: In the Microsoft Advertising ad units section on this page, create an ad unit.

segment.source: For the ad unit type, select Banner if you are using an AdControl, or select Video interstitial if you are using an InterstitialAd.
segment.target: For the ad unit type, select Banner if you are using an AdControl, or select Video interstitial if you are using an InterstitialAd.

segment.source: For more information about this page, see Monetize with ads.
segment.target: For more information about this page, see Monetize with ads.

segment.source: For each generated ad unit, you will see an Application ID and an Ad unit ID on this page.
segment.target: For each generated ad unit, you will see an Application ID and an Ad unit ID on this page.

segment.source: To show ads in your app, you'll need to use these values in your apps code:
segment.target: To show ads in your app, you'll need to use these values in your apps code:

segment.source: If your app shows banner ads, assign these values to the ApplicationId and AdUnitId properties of your AdControl object.
segment.target: If your app shows banner ads, assign these values to the ApplicationId and AdUnitId properties of your AdControl object.

segment.source: If your app shows video interstitial ads, pass these values to the RequestAd method of your InterstitialAd object.
segment.target: If your app shows video interstitial ads, pass these values to the RequestAd method of your InterstitialAd object.

segment.source: Important If your app uses ad mediation to show banner ads from Microsoft (that is, it uses an AdMediatorControl object), you do not need to request ad units.
segment.target: Important If your app uses ad mediation to show banner ads from Microsoft (that is, it uses an AdMediatorControl object), you do not need to request ad units.

segment.source: In this scenario, ad units are automatically generated for you.
segment.target: In this scenario, ad units are automatically generated for you.

segment.source: For more information, see What is the difference: AdMediatorControl or AdControl.
segment.target: For more information, see What is the difference: AdMediatorControl or AdControl.

segment.target: Related topics
